batch.name: Campbell Ch51 Animal Behavior — Olympiad Expansion

questions.question: Fixed action patterns (FAPs) are stereotyped behavioral sequences triggered by specific stimuli. Which of the following best describes the key properties of a FAP?
options: FAPs are highly variable behaviors that differ significantly each time they are performed

FAPs are innate, stereotyped behavioral sequences triggered by a specific sign stimulus (releaser) — once initiated, the motor program runs to completion regardless of changes in sensory feedback; they are species-specific and performed without prior learning, as demonstrated by Lorenz and Tinbergen's studies on the egg-retrieval behavior of the greylag goose
FAPs are entirely learned behaviors that require extensive practice to perform correctly
FAPs are conscious voluntary decisions that can be stopped at any point during execution
questions.explanation: Fixed action patterns are fundamental concepts in classical ethology, formalized by Konrad Lorenz and Nikolaas Tinbergen. Key properties: (1) Innate — FAPs develop without learning, as shown by isolation (Kaspar Hauser) experiments where animals raised without exposure to conspecifics still perform species-typical FAPs. (2) Stereotyped — the motor pattern is highly consistent within a species, performed the same way each time (though minor variations exist). (3) Species-specific — each species has its own repertoire of FAPs. (4) Ballistic — once triggered, the complete sequence runs to completion even if the triggering stimulus is removed. Lorenz demonstrated this with the greylag goose egg-retrieval behavior: if the egg is removed mid-retrieval, the goose completes the bill-tucking motion. (5) Triggered by sign stimuli (releasers) — specific sensory cues that activate an innate releasing mechanism (IRM). Tinbergen showed that three-spined stickleback males attack models with red undersides (sign stimulus for territorial aggression), regardless of overall shape. (6) Threshold varies — the internal motivational state affects how easily a FAP is triggered (vacuum behavior occurs when motivation is very high without a releaser). Modern neuroethology has identified the neural circuits underlying many FAPs, though the strict 'ballistic' criterion has been relaxed somewhat.

questions.question: Inclusive fitness theory, proposed by W.D. Hamilton, explains the evolution of altruistic behavior. What is Hamilton's rule?
options: Hamilton's rule states that altruistic behavior will be favored by natural selection when rB > C, where r is the coefficient of relatedness between altruist and recipient, B is the reproductive benefit to the recipient, and C is the reproductive cost to the altruist — this explains why eusocial Hymenoptera (ants, bees, wasps) with haplodiploid sex determination have unusually high r among sisters (0.75)
Hamilton's rule states that all organisms always behave selfishly to maximize their own reproduction
Hamilton's rule applies only to parental care, not to interactions between siblings or other relatives
Hamilton's rule states that altruism evolves only in species with exactly two offspring per generation
questions.explanation: W.D. Hamilton's 1964 papers on the genetic evolution of social behavior introduced inclusive fitness theory, one of the most important concepts in behavioral ecology. Hamilton's rule: an allele for altruistic behavior will spread when rB > C, where: r = coefficient of relatedness (probability of sharing the allele by descent). For diploid organisms: parent-offspring r = 0.5, full siblings r = 0.5, half-siblings r = 0.25, grandparent-grandchild r = 0.25, cousins r = 0.125. B = reproductive benefit gained by the recipient due to the altruistic act. C = reproductive cost to the altruist. The concept of inclusive fitness = direct fitness (own reproduction) + indirect fitness (reproduction of relatives weighted by r). This explains kin selection — organisms can increase the transmission of their genes by helping relatives reproduce. Haplodiploidy in Hymenoptera creates an asymmetry: sisters share r = 0.75 (they share 100% of their father's haploid genome and 50% of their mother's diploid genome). This makes sisters more related to each other than to their own daughters (r = 0.5), potentially favoring worker sterility — though haplodiploidy alone is insufficient to explain eusociality, as it also predicts reduced investment in brothers (r = 0.25). Hamilton's famous quip: 'I would lay down my life for two brothers or eight cousins' (2 × 0.5 > 1; 8 × 0.125 > 1).

questions.question: Imprinting is a form of learning that occurs during a critical (sensitive) period early in development. What is filial imprinting, and what neural mechanism underlies it?
options: Filial imprinting is the process by which a young precocial bird learns the characteristics of its parent during a brief sensitive period (typically the first 24-48 hours post-hatching) — Lorenz demonstrated this with greylag goslings that imprinted on him; the neural substrate involves the intermediate medial mesopallium (IMM) in the chick forebrain, where synaptic changes encode the visual features of the imprinted object
Imprinting occurs throughout the animal's entire lifespan with equal effectiveness
Imprinting only affects auditory processing and has no visual component
Imprinting is identical to classical conditioning and uses the same neural circuits
questions.explanation: Filial imprinting, described by Konrad Lorenz (Nobel Prize 1973), is a form of rapid, irreversible learning during a critical sensitive period that establishes the identity of the parent figure. Key features: (1) Sensitive period — occurs during a defined developmental window (~12-36 hours post-hatching in chickens, up to ~48 hours in geese). Before and after this window, imprinting is much less effective. (2) Rapid — exposure for as little as 10 minutes can be sufficient. (3) Relatively irreversible — once established, the imprinted preference is stable and difficult to modify. (4) Influences later behavior — filial imprinting determines which individual the young follow (attachment), while sexual imprinting (a related process occurring later) influences mate choice. (5) Species generality — occurs in many precocial birds and some mammals. Neural basis: In domestic chicks, Gabriel Horn and colleagues identified the intermediate medial mesopallium (IMM, formerly IMHV) as the critical brain region. During imprinting: (a) NMDA receptor-dependent synaptic plasticity in IMM encodes visual features of the imprinted object. (b) c-fos expression increases in IMM during the sensitive period. (c) Dendritic spine density changes in IMM neurons. (d) Bilateral IMM lesions prevent imprinting but do not affect already-imprinted preferences (stored elsewhere after consolidation). Option B ignores the sensitive period. Option C is too narrow. Option D mischaracterizes the learning type.

questions.question: Optimal foraging theory predicts that animals will maximize their net energy intake per unit time while foraging. What is the marginal value theorem?
options: The marginal value theorem (Charnov, 1976) predicts that an optimal forager should leave a depleting food patch when the marginal rate of energy gain in that patch drops to the average rate of gain for the habitat as a whole, including travel time between patches — this means animals should stay longer in rich patches and leave poor patches sooner, spending more time traveling when patches are far apart
Animals should always consume all food in a patch before moving to the next one
Animals should spend equal time in every food patch regardless of patch quality
The theorem states that animals should always forage in the nearest patch to minimize travel time
questions.explanation: The marginal value theorem (MVT), formulated by Eric Charnov (1976), is one of the most successful quantitative predictions in behavioral ecology. The model assumes: (1) Food patches are distributed across a habitat, separated by travel time. (2) Within a patch, the rate of food intake decreases over time as the patch is depleted (diminishing returns — a negatively accelerated gain function). (3) The forager cannot simultaneously forage and travel. The optimization: an animal should leave a patch when the instantaneous (marginal) rate of energy gain equals the long-term average rate for the entire habitat. Graphically, this is found by drawing a tangent line from the travel time point to the gain function curve. Predictions: (a) Animals stay longer in richer patches (more food to extract before marginal rate drops to average). (b) Animals stay longer in all patches when travel time between patches increases (average rate is lower, so the marginal rate takes longer to decline to that level). (c) Animals leave patches sooner in habitats with many high-quality patches (average rate is higher). These predictions have been confirmed in many species, including great tits foraging in artificial patches, bumblebees visiting flowers, and starlings feeding nestlings. Deviations from MVT predictions reveal important factors like predation risk, incomplete information, and state-dependent decisions.

questions.question: The waggle dance of honeybees communicates the location of food sources to hive mates. What information is encoded in the dance?
options: The waggle dance, decoded by Karl von Frisch (Nobel Prize 1973), encodes both distance and direction to a food source — the angle of the waggle run relative to vertical on the comb indicates the angle between the food source and the sun's azimuth, while the duration of the waggle phase encodes distance (approximately 1 second per km); the vigor of dancing correlates with food quality
The waggle dance only communicates the type of flower at the food source through different wing-beat frequencies
The waggle dance is a random movement with no informational content
The waggle dance communicates only the distance to food, not its direction
questions.explanation: Karl von Frisch's decoding of the honeybee (Apis mellifera) waggle dance is one of the most celebrated discoveries in animal behavior. The dance is performed on the vertical surface of a dark hive comb: (1) Direction — the waggle phase is a straight run in which the bee waggles its abdomen while walking. The angle of this waggle run relative to straight up (antigravity) on the comb represents the angle between the food source and the sun's azimuth as seen from the hive. Dancing straight up = food in the direction of the sun; straight down = food opposite to the sun; 60° right of vertical = food 60° right of the sun. The dancer compensates for the sun's movement over time. (2) Distance — the duration of the waggle phase correlates with distance to the food. In Apis mellifera, approximately 1 second of waggling indicates ~1 km (varies by subspecies). Distance can also be encoded by the number of waggle cycles and the tempo of the dance circuit. (3) Quality — the vigor, duration, and number of dance circuits correlate with food source quality (nectar concentration, abundance). High-quality sources elicit more enthusiastic dancing, recruiting more foragers. (4) Odor — dance followers also detect floral odors on the dancer's body, aiding source identification. James Gould (1975) confirmed the symbolic nature using artificial light to manipulate the bees' sun reference, showing recruits indeed follow the dance's directional information.

questions.question: Classical (Pavlovian) conditioning and operant (instrumental) conditioning are two fundamental forms of associative learning. What key difference distinguishes them?
options: In classical conditioning, the animal learns an association between two stimuli (a neutral conditioned stimulus paired with an unconditioned stimulus that elicits an innate response), producing a conditioned response — in operant conditioning, the animal learns an association between its own behavior and a consequence (reward or punishment), modifying the frequency of that behavior according to Thorndike's law of effect
Classical and operant conditioning are identical processes with different names
Classical conditioning involves voluntary responses while operant conditioning involves involuntary reflexes
Only vertebrates can undergo classical conditioning, while operant conditioning occurs in all animals
questions.explanation: Classical and operant conditioning represent two distinct forms of associative learning, each with different neural substrates and functional significance. Classical (Pavlovian) conditioning: Discovered by Ivan Pavlov (~1900). An initially neutral conditioned stimulus (CS, e.g., bell tone) is repeatedly paired with an unconditioned stimulus (US, e.g., food) that naturally elicits an unconditioned response (UR, e.g., salivation). After pairing, the CS alone elicits a conditioned response (CR, salivation to the bell). Key features: (a) The animal learns a predictive relationship between stimuli. (b) The response is typically reflexive/involuntary (autonomic). (c) Neural substrate: amygdala (fear conditioning), cerebellum (eyeblink conditioning). Operant (instrumental) conditioning: Formalized by B.F. Skinner (1938), building on Thorndike's law of effect (1898). The animal learns that its own behavior has consequences: behaviors followed by positive outcomes (reinforcement) increase in frequency; behaviors followed by negative outcomes (punishment) decrease. Key features: (a) The animal learns a contingency between action and outcome. (b) Responses are typically voluntary/skeletal. (c) Neural substrate: basal ganglia (striatum), prefrontal cortex, dopaminergic reward pathway (VTA→nucleus accumbens). Both forms show extinction, spontaneous recovery, generalization, and discrimination. The Rescorla-Wagner model (1972) mathematically describes CS-US associative strength changes in classical conditioning.

questions.question: The prisoner's dilemma is a foundational model in behavioral ecology for understanding cooperation. What strategy proved most successful in Axelrod's iterated prisoner's dilemma tournament?
options: Tit-for-tat, a strategy that cooperates on the first move and then copies the opponent's previous move — it succeeds because it is nice (never defects first), retaliatory (immediately punishes defection), forgiving (returns to cooperation after the opponent cooperates), and clear (easy for opponents to recognize and adapt to), promoting stable mutual cooperation in repeated interactions
Always defect — the strategy that maximizes individual payoff regardless of the opponent's behavior
Random — choosing cooperation or defection randomly with equal probability
Always cooperate — unconditionally helping regardless of the opponent's behavior
questions.explanation: Robert Axelrod's famous tournament (1984) invited game theorists to submit strategies for an iterated prisoner's dilemma (IPD) played against each other strategy. The simplest strategy, tit-for-tat (TFT) submitted by Anatol Rapoport, won both tournaments. TFT's properties: (1) Nice — begins by cooperating, establishing a cooperative relationship. (2) Retaliatory — immediately defects after the opponent defects, punishing exploitation. (3) Forgiving — returns to cooperation when the opponent cooperates, allowing recovery from mutual defection. (4) Clear — its simple pattern is easily recognized by other strategies, facilitating mutual cooperation. In the context of biological evolution: (a) Reciprocal altruism (Trivers, 1971) explains cooperation between non-relatives through repeated interactions where future reciprocation is expected. (b) TFT-like strategies are observed in nature: vampire bats share blood meals reciprocally and punish non-reciprocators; cleaner fish and client fish maintain cooperative relationships. (c) For TFT to evolve, individuals must: meet repeatedly, recognize each other, and remember past interactions. (d) 'Always defect' wins single interactions but performs poorly long-term because it never establishes cooperative partnerships. 'Always cooperate' is exploited by defectors. Later work showed tit-for-tat with some generosity (occasional forgiveness of defection) outperforms strict TFT in noisy environments where errors occur.

questions.question: Circadian rhythms are endogenous biological clocks with approximately 24-hour periodicity. In mammals, where is the master circadian clock located, and what is its molecular mechanism?
options: The master circadian clock is in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the anterior hypothalamus — it generates ~24-hour rhythms through interlocking transcription-translation feedback loops: CLOCK and BMAL1 proteins heterodimerize to activate transcription of Period (Per1/2) and Cryptochrome (Cry1/2) genes; PER-CRY complexes accumulate, enter the nucleus, and inhibit CLOCK-BMAL1, suppressing their own transcription; this cycle takes ~24 hours and is entrained to the light-dark cycle via retinohypothalamic tract input from intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells (ipRGCs) containing melanopsin
Circadian rhythms are entirely determined by external light-dark cycles with no internal clock
The master clock is in the pineal gland, which directly detects light through the skull
Circadian rhythms use a purely cytoplasmic mechanism with no gene transcription involved
questions.explanation: The mammalian circadian system is a hierarchical oscillator network with the SCN as the master pacemaker. The SCN (~20,000 neurons in mice, bilateral) generates self-sustained ~24-hour oscillations even in complete darkness (free-running period ~24.2 hours in humans). The molecular clock mechanism involves two interlocking feedback loops: Primary loop: (1) CLOCK and BMAL1 (basic helix-loop-helix PAS domain transcription factors) heterodimerize and bind E-box elements in the promoters of Per1, Per2, Cry1, and Cry2 genes, activating their transcription (positive limb). (2) PER and CRY proteins accumulate in the cytoplasm, heterodimerize, are phosphorylated by casein kinases (CK1δ/ε), and translocate to the nucleus. (3) Nuclear PER-CRY complexes directly inhibit CLOCK-BMAL1 transcriptional activity (negative limb). (4) PER-CRY degradation (ubiquitination by E3 ligases) releases the inhibition, allowing CLOCK-BMAL1 to restart the cycle. Secondary loop: REV-ERBα (repressor) and RORα (activator) regulate Bmal1 transcription, adding robustness. Entrainment: Light detected by melanopsin-containing ipRGCs (intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells) signals via the retinohypothalamic tract (glutamate + PACAP) to the SCN, inducing Per1/Per2 expression and phase-shifting the clock. The SCN synchronizes peripheral clocks in liver, lung, kidney, etc. Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2017 was awarded to Hall, Rosbash, and Young for elucidating the molecular clock mechanism in Drosophila.

questions.question:
Match the following behavioral ecology concepts with their definitions:
(I) Kin selection
(II) Reciprocal altruism
(III) Sexual selection
(IV) Frequency-dependent selection

(P) Cooperative behavior between unrelated individuals that benefits both over repeated interactions, requiring recognition, memory, and punishment of cheaters
(Q) Selection for traits that increase mating success, either through male-male competition (intrasexual) or female choice (intersexual), potentially at the cost of survival
(R) Altruistic behavior toward genetic relatives that increases inclusive fitness, favored when rB > C
(S) A form of natural selection where the fitness of a phenotype depends on its frequency in the population, maintaining behavioral polymorphisms
options: I-R, II-P, III-Q, IV-S
I-P, II-R, III-S, IV-Q
I-Q, II-S, III-R, IV-P
I-S, II-Q, III-P, IV-R
questions.explanation: Kin selection (I-R): Hamilton's concept that natural selection can favor genes promoting altruistic behavior toward relatives because relatives share alleles by descent. The gene's-eye-view: an allele for helping relatives can increase in frequency if the benefit to the recipient (weighted by relatedness) exceeds the cost to the altruist. Examples: alarm calls in Belding's ground squirrels (females call more when relatives are nearby), eusociality in Hymenoptera. Reciprocal altruism (II-P): Trivers (1971) proposed that cooperation between non-relatives can evolve through repeated interactions where each partner reciprocates help. Requirements: repeated encounters, individual recognition, memory of past interactions, and punishment of cheaters. Examples: vampire bat blood sharing, grooming in primates, cleaner fish mutualism. Modeled by iterated prisoner's dilemma. Sexual selection (III-Q): Darwin's (1871) concept of selection for traits that increase mating success, operating through two mechanisms: intrasexual selection (competition between same-sex individuals — antlers, fighting) and intersexual selection (mate choice — peacock tail, bowerbird displays). Can produce exaggerated traits that reduce survival but increase mating success (Fisherian runaway, handicap principle/Zahavi). Frequency-dependent selection (IV-S): Fitness depends on how common a phenotype is. Negative FDS maintains polymorphisms (rare morphs have higher fitness — e.g., predator search image, alternative mating strategies in side-blotched lizards). Positive FDS eliminates rare variants.

questions.question: Song learning in songbirds involves a critical period and a process remarkably similar to human language acquisition. What are the two phases of song learning in species like the zebra finch?
options: Song learning occurs in two phases: a sensory phase (approximately days 20-65 post-hatching in zebra finch) during which the bird memorizes a tutor's song template through auditory exposure, and a sensorimotor phase (~35-90 days) during which the bird practices and refines its own song through auditory feedback (comparing its own output to the memorized template) — the HVC and RA brain nuclei control song production while Area X and LMAN are essential for song learning
Songbirds are born with a complete song that requires no learning
Song learning occurs throughout the bird's entire life with no critical periods
Song learning involves only motor practice — auditory input is unnecessary
questions.explanation: Birdsong learning is one of the best-studied examples of vocal learning in animals and has strong parallels to human speech acquisition. In zebra finches (closed-ended learners that crystallize a single song): Sensory (memorization) phase (~days 20-65): The young bird listens to an adult tutor (usually the father) and forms an auditory memory (template) of the song. Isolation during this period results in abnormal song. Cross-fostering demonstrates that the bird preferentially copies its social tutor over audio playback (social influence on learning). Sensorimotor (practice) phase (~days 35-90, overlapping with sensory phase): The bird begins producing subsong (analogous to infant babbling) — variable, quiet, unstructured vocalizations. Through practice with auditory feedback (comparing its own vocalizations to the memorized template), the bird gradually refines its song into plastic song and finally crystallized song (~90 days). Deafening during this phase prevents normal song development. Song system nuclei: HVC (proper name) → RA (robust nucleus of arcopallium) = motor pathway for song production. HVC → Area X → DLM → LMAN (lateral magnocellular nucleus of anterior nidopallium) → RA = anterior forebrain pathway (AFP) essential for song learning and variability. LMAN lesions prevent song learning but not adult song production. FoxP2 (related to human FOXP2 speech gene) is expressed in Area X and is required for normal song learning.

questions.question: In a study of predator-prey dynamics, researchers present different colored prey (moths) on tree bark backgrounds. They find that cryptic (bark-matching) moths survive significantly longer than conspicuous moths, but a small percentage (~5%) of brightly colored (aposematic) moths also survive well. Over 100 generations, the population stabilizes with ~90% cryptic and ~10% aposematic individuals. What evolutionary mechanisms explain this stable polymorphism?
options: The polymorphism is maintained by frequency-dependent selection — at low frequency, aposematic moths benefit from predator avoidance learning (predators quickly learn to avoid their warning colors after an unpleasant experience), while at high frequency the cost of initial predator sampling increases proportionally; cryptic moths benefit at high frequency because predators develop a search image, but at low frequency they are found randomly — the equilibrium frequency reflects where the fitness of both strategies is equal
The brightly colored moths survive by random chance and the polymorphism is not stable
All moths will eventually become aposematic because warning coloration is always beneficial
The 10% aposematic moths are maintained by constant immigration from another population
questions.explanation: This stable polymorphism illustrates negative frequency-dependent selection, a major mechanism for maintaining behavioral and morphological diversity in populations. The dynamics: Aposematic (warning-colored) moths: (1) At low frequency, they benefit because predators that sample and find them unpalatable quickly form an avoidance memory (one-trial learning in many birds). The 'cost of advertising' (being initially conspicuous) is shared among fewer individuals. (2) As aposematic frequency increases, more naive predators must sample them (larger cost), and the per-capita benefit decreases. (3) Automimicry (palatable mimics of aposematic models) may also evolve at high aposematic frequency. Cryptic moths: (1) At high frequency, predators form search images (cognitive templates optimized for detecting common prey), increasing predation on common cryptic morphs. (2) At low frequency, predators do not develop specific search images, and crypsis is more effective. (3) Apostatic selection (predators disproportionately taking common morphs) stabilizes the polymorphism. Equilibrium: The two strategies have equal fitness at the observed frequencies (~90:10). This is analogous to evolutionary game theory's mixed ESS (evolutionarily stable strategy). Similar frequency-dependent polymorphisms are found in: side-blotched lizard mating strategies (rock-paper-scissors game), Batesian mimicry systems, and shell color polymorphisms in snails.

questions.question: Tinbergen's four questions provide a comprehensive framework for studying animal behavior. What are the four levels of analysis?
options: Tinbergen's four questions address behavior at both proximate and ultimate levels: (1) Causation/mechanism — what physiological/neural mechanisms produce the behavior? (2) Development/ontogeny — how does the behavior develop during the individual's lifetime? (3) Function/adaptation — what is the survival/reproductive benefit? (4) Phylogeny/evolution — how did the behavior evolve over evolutionary time?
The four questions are: where, when, how fast, and how loud the behavior occurs
Tinbergen proposed only two questions — mechanism and function — not four
The four questions apply only to invertebrate behavior, not to vertebrates
questions.explanation: Nikolaas Tinbergen (Nobel Prize 1973, shared with Lorenz and von Frisch) proposed in his 1963 paper 'On Aims and Methods of Ethology' that a complete understanding of any behavior requires answering four complementary questions, organized at two levels: Proximate (how) questions: (1) Causation/Mechanism — what are the immediate physiological, neurological, hormonal, and sensory mechanisms that produce the behavior? Example: male stickleback aggression is triggered by the sign stimulus of a red belly, processed by visual neurons, and executed by specific motor circuits activated by testosterone. (2) Development/Ontogeny — how does the behavior change during the individual's lifetime through maturation, learning, and experience? Example: song learning in birds involves a sensitive period, tutor exposure, and practice. Ultimate (why) questions: (3) Function/Adaptation — what is the current survival or reproductive advantage of the behavior? Addressed through experiments and comparative methods. Example: alarm calling reduces predation on relatives (kin selection). (4) Phylogeny/Evolution — what is the evolutionary history of the behavior? How has it changed across related species? Addressed through phylogenetic comparative analysis. Example: tracing the evolution of courtship displays across duck species. These four questions are complementary, not competing — a complete explanation requires all four. Confusing proximate and ultimate explanations is a common error in behavioral biology.

questions.question: Eusociality, the highest form of social organization, is characterized by three features. What are they, and in which animal groups has eusociality evolved?
options: Eusociality is defined by: (1) reproductive division of labor (only one or few individuals reproduce), (2) cooperative brood care (non-reproductive workers care for offspring of the queen), and (3) overlapping generations (at least two adult generations coexist in the colony) — eusociality has evolved independently in Hymenoptera (ants, bees, wasps), termites (Isoptera), some shrimp (Synalpheus), naked mole-rats, and possibly some aphids and thrips
Eusociality simply means any species that lives in groups
Eusociality is found exclusively in insects and cannot evolve in vertebrates
The only requirement for eusociality is that individuals forage together
questions.explanation: Eusociality, defined by E.O. Wilson and expanded by subsequent researchers, represents the pinnacle of social evolution. The three defining criteria: (1) Reproductive division of labor — a colony has one or few reproductive individuals (queens, and sometimes kings in termites) while the majority are non-reproductive workers. In extreme cases like honeybees, the queen is the sole egg-layer, while up to 60,000 workers are functionally sterile. (2) Cooperative brood care (alloparenting) — workers collectively raise offspring that are not their own, performing tasks like foraging, nursing, nest defense, and thermoregulation. (3) Overlapping generations — the colony persists across generations, with parents and offspring coexisting as adults, enabling transmission of colony-level adaptations and division of labor. Taxonomic distribution: Eusociality has evolved independently at least 10-15 times. Hymenoptera: all ~20,000 ant species are eusocial, plus some bees (honeybees, stingless bees, some halictid bees) and wasps (Polistes, Vespula). Termites (Blattodea: Termitidae): all ~3,000 species are eusocial, but they are diploid, disproving the hypothesis that haplodiploidy is necessary. Crustacea: snapping shrimp (Synalpheus regalis) — the only known marine eusocial species. Mammalia: naked mole-rats (Heterocephalus glaber) and Damaraland mole-rats — the only known eusocial mammals. Other: some aphids, thrips, and ambrosia beetles show eusocial features.

questions.question: Aposematism (warning coloration) and Batesian mimicry are related anti-predator strategies. What is Batesian mimicry, and what conditions must be met for it to be evolutionarily stable?
options: Batesian mimicry occurs when a palatable (harmless) species evolves to resemble an unpalatable (toxic or dangerous) model species — it is effective only when: (1) the mimic is rarer than the model (otherwise predators learn the pattern is often profitable), (2) the model is truly noxious and memorable, and (3) predators use visual learning to generalize avoidance from model to mimic; too many mimics relative to models degrades the signal (frequency-dependent selection against the mimic at high frequency)
Batesian mimicry is when two toxic species resemble each other to reinforce predator avoidance
Batesian mimicry only occurs between plant species, not animals
Batesian mimicry requires the mimic to be more toxic than the model
questions.explanation: Batesian mimicry (Henry Walter Bates, 1862, studying Amazonian butterflies) is an evolutionary relationship between a palatable mimic and an unpalatable model. The mimic gains protection by resembling the model, which predators have learned to avoid. Conditions for stability: (1) Rarity of mimic — if mimics become too common relative to models, predators encounter mimics frequently, learn that the pattern is often rewarding, and the signal loses its protective value. This creates negative frequency-dependent selection on the mimic. (2) Noxiousness of model — the model must be sufficiently unpleasant (toxic, venomous, bad-tasting) that predators form strong avoidance memories. (3) Predator learning — predators must use visual pattern recognition and generalise their learned avoidance from model encounters to mimic encounters. (4) Spatial overlap — model and mimic must co-occur in the same habitat. Classic examples: Viceroy butterfly (Limenitis archippus) mimicking the Monarch (Danaus plexippus) — though recent work shows viceroys are mildly unpalatable, making this a case between Batesian and Mullerian mimicry. Non-venomous king snakes mimicking coral snakes. Hoverflies mimicking bees/wasps. This contrasts with Mullerian mimicry (Fritz Muller, 1879), where two or more genuinely unpalatable species converge on the same warning pattern, sharing the cost of predator education.

questions.question: A researcher hypothesizes that female peafowl (peahens) prefer males with more elaborate tail (train) displays because these honestly signal male genetic quality (the handicap principle). What experimental approach would most rigorously test this hypothesis?
options: Count the number of eyespots on male trains and observe which males mate most frequently

Manipulate male train length by cutting or adding feathers (creating shorter-than-normal and longer-than-normal trains), then measure female choice in controlled mate-choice trials — additionally, measure offspring fitness (survival, parasite resistance, growth rate) from fathers with naturally different train sizes to test whether train elaboration honestly signals heritable genetic quality; include controls with sham-manipulated males
Compare train sizes across different peafowl species in a phylogenetic analysis
Measure testosterone levels in males with different train sizes
questions.explanation: Testing the handicap principle (Zahavi, 1975) requires demonstrating both that females prefer the trait AND that the trait honestly signals quality. A rigorous experimental design: (1) Experimental manipulation of train length: Cut eyespot feathers from some males (reduced), attach extra feathers to others (enhanced), and sham-manipulate controls (cut and reattach same feathers). This isolates train elaboration from other male traits (territory quality, courtship vigor). Petrie and Halliday (1994) performed this experiment. (2) Mate choice trials: Present females with a choice between manipulated and control males in semi-natural enclosures. Measure approach distance, time spent near each male, and copulation frequency. If females prefer enhanced males, this confirms the female preference. (3) Honest signaling test (critical): Cross-foster offspring to control for maternal effects, then measure: (a) Offspring survival to independence. (b) Parasite resistance (measure ectoparasite loads, immune response assays). (c) Growth rate and condition. If sons of males with naturally more elaborate trains have higher fitness, the train is an honest (condition-dependent) signal of genetic quality. (4) Condition-dependence: Test whether males in better nutritional condition grow more elaborate trains, as the handicap principle requires the trait to be costly enough that only high-quality males can maintain it. Marion Petrie's work showed that peahens mating with more ornamented males produced offspring with higher survival rates. Option A is correlational. Option C tests phylogeny. Option D measures a proximate mechanism.

questions.question: Habituation is the simplest form of non-associative learning. What distinguishes habituation from sensory adaptation?
options: Habituation is a decrease in behavioral response to a repeated, harmless stimulus that occurs through synaptic changes in the neural circuit — unlike sensory adaptation (which is a peripheral receptor phenomenon), habituation involves changes in interneuron and motor neuron activity; it is stimulus-specific, can be reversed by dishabituation (a novel strong stimulus restores the response), and was extensively studied by Kandel in the Aplysia gill-withdrawal reflex
Habituation and sensory adaptation are identical processes occurring at the receptor level
Habituation is permanent — once habituated, the response never returns
Habituation only occurs in vertebrates with complex nervous systems
questions.explanation: Habituation is a form of non-associative learning in which repeated presentation of a benign stimulus leads to a progressive decrease in response. Eric Kandel (Nobel Prize 2000) elucidated the molecular mechanism using the gill-withdrawal reflex of Aplysia californica: A gentle touch to the siphon normally triggers gill withdrawal through a simple circuit: siphon sensory neurons → motor neurons → gill muscles. With repeated stimulation, the response decreases. The mechanism is presynaptic: (1) Reduced Ca2+ influx into the sensory neuron terminal (fewer voltage-gated Ca2+ channels available). (2) Decreased neurotransmitter (glutamate) release at the sensory-motor synapse. (3) Short-term habituation involves covalent modification of existing proteins; long-term habituation requires protein synthesis and structural changes (reduced synaptic contacts). Key distinctions from sensory adaptation: (a) Sensory adaptation occurs at the receptor level (e.g., Pacinian corpuscle filtering sustained pressure). (b) Habituation occurs at synapses within the neural circuit. (c) Habituation is stimulus-specific — habituated to one stimulus, the animal still responds fully to different stimuli. (d) Dishabituation — a strong or novel stimulus restores the habituated response, proving the sensory pathway is intact. Habituation occurs across all animals with nervous systems, from cnidarians to humans.

questions.question: The handicap principle (Zahavi, 1975) provides an explanation for the evolution of costly ornamental traits. What does it propose?
options: The handicap principle proposes that sexually selected traits (like the peacock's tail) are honest signals of genetic quality precisely because they are costly to produce and maintain — only males in good condition can afford the survival handicap imposed by the trait, so the trait cannot be faked by low-quality males; this resolves the paradox of why females prefer traits that reduce male survival
The handicap principle states that ornamental traits have no cost and evolve by random drift
The principle applies only to auditory signals, not visual displays
The handicap principle predicts that all males should have equally elaborate ornaments
questions.explanation: Amotz Zahavi's handicap principle (1975, formalized mathematically by Grafen 1990) resolves a key problem in sexual selection theory: how can female preference for costly male traits be maintained by selection? Fisher's runaway sexual selection explains how preferences and traits coevolve but does not explain why females benefit. Zahavi proposed: (1) Costly traits are honest signals — a large peacock tail, bright coloration, or elaborate song impose real survival costs (increased predation, energy expenditure, parasites). (2) Only high-quality males can bear these costs — a male with good genes, high nutritional condition, or strong immune function can produce and maintain an elaborate trait while still surviving. A low-quality male cannot; if he produced the trait, the cost would be fatal. (3) Therefore, the trait is an unfakeable signal of quality — females choosing males with elaborate traits are selecting for good genes that will benefit their offspring. This is formally an example of a 'costly signaling' or 'index' signal in animal communication theory. Supporting evidence: (a) Condition-dependent expression: testosterone-dependent ornaments are suppressed by parasites and poor nutrition. (b) Hamilton and Zuk (1982): bright coloration in birds correlates with low parasite loads. (c) Experimental studies: female barn swallows prefer males with longer tail streamers; offspring of long-tailed males have higher survival. (d) Immunocompetence handicap hypothesis: testosterone promotes ornament development but suppresses immune function.

questions.question: Migration involves remarkable feats of navigation. What compass mechanisms do migratory birds use to determine direction?
options: Migratory birds use multiple redundant compass systems: (1) a sun compass with time compensation (using the circadian clock to account for the sun's movement across the sky), (2) a stellar compass calibrated during development by observing the rotation of the night sky around the celestial pole, and (3) a magnetic compass based on the inclination (dip angle) of Earth's magnetic field lines, likely using cryptochrome-based radical pair mechanisms in the retina
Birds navigate exclusively by following landmarks and have no internal compass
Birds use only the Earth's magnetic field and cannot navigate using celestial cues
Migration direction is entirely determined genetically with no calibration by environmental cues
questions.explanation: Bird navigation is one of the most sophisticated orientation systems in the animal kingdom, using at least three compass mechanisms: (1) Sun compass: Birds determine direction from the sun's position, compensated for time of day using their circadian clock. Demonstrated by clock-shift experiments (Kramer, Schmidt-Koenig): advancing the clock by 6 hours shifts the bird's directional choice by ~90°. Young birds must learn the sun's arc. (2) Star compass: Emlen (1967, 1975) showed that indigo buntings learn the night sky's rotational center (celestial pole) during development by observing stellar rotation in a planetarium. Birds raised under a planetarium sky rotating around Betelgeuse oriented as if Betelgeuse were the pole star. This compass is learned, not innate. (3) Magnetic compass: Birds detect Earth's magnetic field (~25-65 µT) using an inclination compass — they sense the angle between the field lines and the horizontal, not polarity (they cannot distinguish magnetic north from south). The leading mechanism involves cryptochrome proteins (Cry1a, Cry4) in the retina, where light-generated radical pairs have spin dynamics sensitive to magnetic field direction. This is disrupted by oscillating magnetic fields in the radiofrequency range. Additionally, a magnetite-based system in the upper beak (trigeminal nerve-innervated) may provide magnetic map information (field intensity) for determining geographic position. These compasses are hierarchically calibrated: the magnetic compass calibrates the star compass, which calibrates the sun compass.

questions.question: Game theory applies evolutionary concepts to behavioral strategies. What is an Evolutionarily Stable Strategy (ESS)?
options: An ESS (Maynard Smith and Price, 1973) is a strategy that, when adopted by most members of a population, cannot be invaded by any alternative (mutant) strategy — if a population playing the ESS is invaded by a rare mutant using a different strategy, the mutant will have lower fitness than residents and will be eliminated by natural selection; the classic hawk-dove game demonstrates that pure hawk or pure dove populations are not ESSes, but a mixed ESS exists
An ESS is the strategy that produces the maximum possible payoff for any individual
An ESS must be a genetically fixed behavior that cannot change
ESS applies only to cooperation, not to competitive interactions
questions.explanation: John Maynard Smith and George Price (1973) introduced evolutionary game theory to biology, providing a rigorous framework for analyzing behavioral strategies when the fitness of a strategy depends on what others are doing (frequency-dependent selection). Formal definition: A strategy I is an ESS if, for any alternative strategy J: (a) E(I,I) > E(J,I), OR (b) E(I,I) = E(J,I) and E(I,J) > E(J,J), where E(X,Y) is the payoff to strategy X when interacting with strategy Y. The hawk-dove game: Hawk = always escalate fights. Dove = display but retreat if opponent escalates. Resource value: V. Cost of injury: C (assume C > V). Payoffs: H vs. H: (V-C)/2 each (negative if C > V). H vs. D: H gets V, D gets 0. D vs. D: V/2 each. If all hawks: average payoff = (V-C)/2 (negative), so dove mutant gets 0 > (V-C)/2 — dove invades. If all doves: average payoff = V/2, but hawk mutant gets V > V/2 — hawk invades. Neither pure strategy is an ESS. Mixed ESS: population plays hawk with probability p = V/C, dove with probability 1 - V/C. At this frequency, hawk and dove have equal fitness, and no invasion is possible. Applications: territorial behavior, contest escalation, parental investment, signaling games, producer-scrounger dynamics, sex ratios (Fisher's principle: 1:1 sex ratio is an ESS).

questions.question: Pheromones are chemical signals used for intraspecific communication. What is the difference between primer pheromones and releaser pheromones?
options: Releaser pheromones trigger an immediate behavioral response (e.g., alarm pheromones in ants cause immediate defensive behavior, sex pheromones like bombykol attract male silkmoths from kilometers away), while primer pheromones cause longer-term physiological changes (e.g., queen mandibular pheromone in honeybees suppresses worker ovary development, and the Lee-Boot effect where female mouse urine suppresses estrous cycles in group-housed females)
Primer pheromones are detected by the main olfactory system while releasers use the vomeronasal organ exclusively
There is no difference — all pheromones produce immediate behavioral responses
Primer pheromones only exist in plants, while releaser pheromones only exist in animals
questions.explanation: Pheromones (Karlson and Luscher, 1959) are chemicals released by one individual that affect the behavior or physiology of conspecifics. They are classified by their effects: Releaser pheromones cause immediate, reversible behavioral responses: (a) Sex pheromones — bombykol (E-10-Z-12-hexadecadien-1-ol) released by female silk moths (Bombyx mori) attracts males from >10 km downwind; detected by male antennae with extraordinary sensitivity (~200 molecules). (b) Alarm pheromones — formic acid and various ketones in ants trigger immediate defensive aggregation and attack behavior. (c) Trail pheromones — volatile compounds laid by foraging ants guide nest-mates to food sources. (d) Aggregation pheromones — attract conspecifics to resources (bark beetles). Primer pheromones cause long-term physiological changes by altering endocrine function: (a) Queen mandibular pheromone (QMP) in honeybees — 9-ODA and other compounds suppress worker ovary development, prevent queen-rearing behavior, and attract drones during mating flights. (b) Lee-Boot effect — pheromones in female mouse urine suppress estrous cycles in group-housed females. (c) Whitten effect — male mouse urine synchronizes estrous cycles in females. (d) Bruce effect — male mouse pheromones (detected via vomeronasal organ, V2R receptors) can terminate pregnancy in recently mated females exposed to a novel male. (e) Maturation pheromones in locusts — trigger transition from solitary to gregarious phase. Both types can be detected by either the main olfactory epithelium or the vomeronasal organ (in species that possess it).

questions.question: A behavioral ecologist studies foraging decisions of great tits (Parus major) in an aviary with two patch types: high-quality (HQ, providing 5 mealworms/minute initially, declining) and low-quality (LQ, providing 2 mealworms/minute initially, declining). Travel time between patches is either 5 seconds (short) or 30 seconds (long). Data shows that birds stay longer in both patch types when travel time is 30 seconds compared to 5 seconds. What does this result support?
options: The result supports the marginal value theorem prediction that animals should stay longer in all patches when travel time between patches increases, because the average rate of return for the habitat is lower when travel consumes more time — the optimal departure point (where marginal rate equals average rate) is reached later when the average rate is reduced by longer travel
Birds stay longer because they are tired from traveling and need to rest
This result contradicts optimal foraging theory and suggests birds forage randomly
The longer stay is due to birds having difficulty finding the exit from each patch
questions.explanation: This classic experimental result directly validates one of the key predictions of Charnov's marginal value theorem (MVT). The MVT predicts that the optimal time to leave a depleting patch is when the instantaneous (marginal) rate of gain drops to the average rate for the entire habitat. The average rate includes: (total food gained across all patches) / (total time including foraging + traveling). When travel time increases: (1) Total time increases for the same amount of foraging. (2) Therefore, the average rate of gain for the habitat decreases. (3) In each patch, the marginal rate of gain starts high and declines as the patch depletes. (4) With a lower average rate to match, the marginal rate takes longer to decline to that level. (5) Therefore, the optimal departure time is later — birds should stay longer in ALL patches. Graphically: the tangent line from the (later) travel time departure point on the x-axis touches the gain curve at a later time, corresponding to more food extracted before leaving. Cowie (1977) elegantly tested this with great tits in an aviary where travel time was manipulated by placing barriers between patches. Results quantitatively matched MVT predictions. The same principle explains why: commuters with longer drives stay at work longer, bees visiting flowers farther from the hive extract more nectar per flower, and bears fishing for salmon spend more time per pool in rivers with widely spaced pools.

questions.question: Parental investment theory (Trivers, 1972) explains patterns of sexual selection. What does the theory predict about which sex will compete for mates and which will be choosy?
options: The sex that invests more in each offspring (typically females in mammals — due to pregnancy, lactation, and obligate maternal care) will be the choosier sex, while the sex with lower investment per offspring (typically males) will compete more intensely for access to the high-investing sex — this explains why sexual selection often acts more strongly on males, producing greater sexual dimorphism, and predicts role reversals in species where males invest more (e.g., pipefish, jacanas)
Males are always competitive and females always choosy, regardless of parental investment
The species with more individuals is always the competitive sex
Parental investment has no relationship to mate choice or competition patterns
questions.explanation: Robert Trivers' parental investment theory (1972) provides the fundamental framework for understanding sex differences in mating behavior. Core logic: (1) Parental investment = any investment in an offspring that increases that offspring's survival at the cost of the parent's ability to invest in other offspring. (2) The sex with higher obligate parental investment per offspring has a lower potential reproductive rate and becomes the limiting resource for the other sex. (3) The lower-investing sex can increase reproductive success by mating with multiple partners, leading to intense competition for access to the high-investing sex. (4) The high-investing sex benefits from being choosy because each reproductive attempt is costly — choosing a high-quality mate maximizes return on investment. In most mammals: females invest heavily (pregnancy, lactation, parental care), are choosy, and limit male reproductive success. Males invest minimally per offspring, compete intensely (intrasexual selection: fights, displays), and are subject to strong sexual selection producing dimorphism. Role-reversal species: (a) Pipefish and seahorses — males brood young in a pouch; females compete for males and are more colorful. (b) Jacanas — males incubate eggs; females are larger, territorial, and polyandrous. (c) Mormon crickets — when food is scarce, males become choosy about which females to offer their spermatophylax (nutritious nuptial gift). Bateman's principle (1948) formalized the relationship: male fitness variance is higher than female fitness variance because males benefit more from additional matings.

questions.question: Spatial learning enables animals to navigate their environment. What is a cognitive map, and which brain structure is critical for its formation?
options: A cognitive map is an internal representation of the spatial relationships between landmarks in an animal's environment, allowing flexible navigation to goals from novel starting points — the hippocampus is critical for cognitive map formation, as demonstrated by place cells that fire when an animal occupies specific locations, and by studies showing that hippocampal lesions impair spatial learning in the Morris water maze
A cognitive map is simply a series of left-right turn decisions memorized in sequence
The cerebellum is the sole brain structure required for spatial navigation
Cognitive maps can only be formed by humans and do not exist in other animals
questions.explanation: Edward Tolman (1948) first proposed the concept of cognitive maps based on rat maze-learning experiments showing that rats learn spatial relationships, not just stimulus-response chains. Key evidence: (1) Latent learning — rats exploring a maze without reward later find food faster than naive rats, showing they learned the maze layout without reinforcement. (2) Novel shortcuts — rats take shortcuts they have never traversed, requiring knowledge of spatial relationships between locations. Hippocampus and spatial memory: (a) O'Keefe and Dostrovsky (1971) discovered place cells in the hippocampus — neurons that fire only when an animal occupies a specific location (place field). Collections of place cells form a neural map of the environment. John O'Keefe and May-Britt and Edvard Moser (Nobel Prize 2014) identified grid cells in the entorhinal cortex — neurons that fire at multiple locations arranged in a hexagonal grid, providing a metric coordinate system. (b) Morris water maze: hippocampal lesions severely impair rats' ability to find a hidden platform using spatial cues. (c) London taxi drivers (Maguire et al., 2000) have enlarged posterior hippocampi, and the enlargement correlates with years of experience navigating London. (d) Food-caching birds (Clark's nutcracker, black-capped chickadee) have relatively larger hippocampi than non-caching species, and hippocampal volume increases seasonally during caching. (e) Head direction cells in the subiculum and border cells in the entorhinal cortex complement place cells and grid cells to form a complete navigation system.

questions.question: Honest signaling theory predicts that animal signals must have some mechanism ensuring reliability. What are the main mechanisms that maintain signal honesty?
options: Three main mechanisms maintain signal honesty: (1) cost-based (handicap) signals — production or maintenance costs ensure only high-quality individuals can produce elaborate signals (peacock tails, red carotenoid pigmentation); (2) index signals — physically constrained signals that are unfakeable (body size determines dominant frequency of vocalizations, horn size limited by skull growth); (3) punishment of dishonest signalers — receivers retaliate against cheaters, making dishonesty costly (mantis shrimp bluff about fighting ability but risk escalated attacks if caught)
All animal signals are always honest and no enforcement mechanism is needed
Animal signals are purely arbitrary and convey no reliable information about the signaler
Only visual signals can be honest; acoustic and chemical signals are always dishonest
questions.explanation: Signal honesty is crucial for communication systems to be evolutionarily stable. If signals were always dishonest, receivers would evolve to ignore them, collapsing the communication system. Three mechanisms maintain reliability: (1) Cost-based (handicap) signals: The cost of producing or maintaining the signal ensures honesty because the marginal cost of increasing signal intensity is higher for low-quality than high-quality signaler. Examples: carotenoid-based plumage (red/orange/yellow) requires dietary carotenoids that are also used by the immune system — parasitized or poorly-nourished birds cannot produce bright plumage without immune compromise. Testosterone-dependent ornaments suppress immune function (immunocompetence handicap hypothesis). (2) Index signals: Mechanistically linked to the quality being signaled, making them impossible to fake. Body size constrains vocalization frequency (larger larynx → lower formant frequencies in red deer roars). Antler/horn size is limited by body growth and mineralization capacity. Claw size in fiddler crabs is constrained by body size. (3) Social enforcement: Receivers punish detected dishonesty. Paper wasps (Polistes) with experimentally darkened facial patterns (fake dominance signals) receive more aggression from colony mates. Mantis shrimp that have recently molted sometimes display threat signals despite lacking fighting ability (bluffing), but opponents may call the bluff and attack. Social punishment maintains honesty through receiver retaliation. Some systems also maintain honesty through shared interests (alarm calls benefit both caller and related receivers) or through repeated interactions where reputation matters (cleaner fish maintain honesty to retain clients).

questions.question:
Match the following learning types with their characteristics:
(I) Classical conditioning
(II) Operant conditioning
(III) Habituation
(IV) Insight learning

(P) Non-associative learning where repeated exposure to a harmless stimulus leads to decreased response; involves presynaptic depression at sensory-motor synapses
(Q) Novel problem-solving without trial-and-error, involving mental manipulation of concepts before acting — demonstrated by Kohler's chimpanzees stacking boxes to reach bananas
(R) Association between a neutral stimulus and a biologically significant stimulus, producing a conditioned response; neural substrates include amygdala (fear) and cerebellum (eyeblink)
(S) Association between an animal's own behavior and its consequences; reinforced behaviors increase in frequency; involves dopaminergic reward pathways in the basal ganglia
options: I-R, II-S, III-P, IV-Q
I-S, II-R, III-Q, IV-P
I-P, II-Q, III-R, IV-S
I-Q, II-P, III-S, IV-R
questions.explanation: Classical conditioning (I-R): Pavlov's paradigm where a neutral conditioned stimulus (CS, e.g., tone) is paired with an unconditioned stimulus (US, e.g., food → salivation). After pairing, the CS alone elicits a conditioned response. The animal learns a predictive relationship between stimuli. Neural substrates are well-characterized: amygdala for fear conditioning (tone + shock → freezing), cerebellum (interpositus nucleus) for eyeblink conditioning (tone + airpuff → blink), and nucleus accumbens for appetitive conditioning. Operant conditioning (II-S): Thorndike/Skinner's paradigm where behaviors are modified by their consequences. Positive reinforcement (reward) increases behavior; negative reinforcement (removing aversive stimulus) increases behavior; punishment decreases behavior. The dopaminergic mesolimbic pathway (VTA → nucleus accumbens) signals reward prediction errors (Schultz et al.): dopamine spikes when reward exceeds expectation, driving learning. The dorsal striatum stores learned action-outcome associations. Habituation (III-P): The simplest learning form. Studied extensively by Kandel in Aplysia: repeated siphon stimulation → decreased sensory neuron → motor neuron synaptic transmission due to reduced Ca2+ influx and vesicle depletion at presynaptic terminals. Stimulus-specific and reversible by dishabituation. Insight learning (IV-Q): Wolfgang Kohler (1925) observed that chimpanzees could solve novel problems (reaching suspended bananas) by apparently combining previously learned elements (stacking boxes, using sticks) without trial-and-error. Requires internal mental representation and is seen in corvids, great apes, and possibly dolphins. The neural basis likely involves prefrontal cortex.

questions.question: Alarm calling in vervet monkeys demonstrates semantic communication. What makes vervet alarm calls particularly noteworthy?
options: Vervet monkeys (Chlorocebus pygerythrus) produce acoustically distinct alarm calls for different predator types — eagle alarms cause monkeys to look up and descend from trees, leopard alarms cause them to climb trees, and snake alarms cause them to look down and stand bipedally; Seyfarth, Cheney, and Marler (1980) demonstrated referential signaling by playing back recorded calls in the absence of predators, eliciting appropriate predator-specific escape responses
Vervet monkeys produce only a single alarm call type used for all predators
Alarm calls in vervets are entirely learned with no innate component
Vervet alarm calls are identical to human language in their complexity and grammar
questions.explanation: Seyfarth, Cheney, and Marler's 1980 study is a landmark in animal communication research, demonstrating functionally referential signaling in a non-human primate. Key findings: (1) Three acoustically distinct alarm call types: 'Rraup' (eagle/raptor alarm) — short, low-pitched. 'Bark' (leopard alarm) — loud, tonal. 'Chutter' (snake alarm) — high-pitched, staccato. (2) Predator-specific responses: Eagle alarm → look up, run into dense bush or descend from exposed tree perch. Leopard alarm → climb to thin outer branches of nearest tree (leopards cannot follow). Snake alarm → stand bipedally, scan ground, mob the snake. (3) Critical experiment: Recorded calls played back through hidden speakers in the absence of any predator elicited the appropriate escape response, proving the calls themselves carry predator-type information (functionally referential). (4) Developmental evidence: Infant vervets make alarm calls but initially overgeneralize (eagle alarm for any aerial object, including falling leaves). Adults respond selectively — reinforcing correct calls by looking up and giving their own eagle alarm when an infant correctly calls for a raptor, but not responding to false alarms. This suggests some innate predisposition refined by experience. (5) Audience effects: callers are more likely to give alarms when vulnerable kin are present (kin selection). While remarkable, vervet calls differ from true language: they lack syntax, generativity, and displacement (referring to things not present). Similar referential alarm systems are found in prairie dogs, Diana monkeys, and some bird species.

questions.question: Territoriality is a common behavioral strategy for resource defense. Under what conditions is territorial behavior predicted to be economically defensible?
options: According to the economic defensibility model (Brown, 1964), territories are maintained when the benefits of exclusive resource access (food, mates, nest sites) exceed the costs of defense (energy expenditure, risk of injury, time spent patrolling) — territoriality is predicted when resources are moderately abundant and predictable; at very low resource density, defense costs are too high for insufficient returns, and at very high density, defense is unnecessary because resources are superabundant
Animals defend territories regardless of resource density or defense costs
Territoriality only occurs in birds and mammals, never in other taxa
Territory size is always the same regardless of resource distribution
questions.explanation: Jerram Brown's (1964) economic defensibility model applies cost-benefit analysis to territorial behavior. The model predicts: (1) Benefits of territoriality: exclusive access to food, mates, or other resources increases the territory holder's fitness. Benefits depend on resource density and quality within the territory. (2) Costs of territoriality: energy spent patrolling boundaries, time lost from foraging or mating, risk of injury from territorial disputes, and increased conspicuousness to predators. (3) Net benefit curve: At low resource density, territories must be very large to provide sufficient resources, making defense costs prohibitive — no territoriality (e.g., desert birds often flock rather than defend territories). At moderate resource density, a defensible territory provides net benefits — optimal conditions for territoriality. At high resource density, the marginal benefit of excluding competitors decreases because resources are superabundant — territoriality breaks down (e.g., some hummingbird species abandon territory defense when flower density is very high). Predictions confirmed by: (a) Golden-winged sunbirds defend nectar-rich flower patches only when nectar is moderately abundant. (b) Territory size decreases with increasing food density (inverse relationship, confirmed in many species). (c) Pied wagtails share territories with satellites when food becomes scarce (cost of defending alone exceeds benefit). (d) Juvenile salmon switch from territorial to schooling behavior as population density increases. The model also predicts that territorial behavior should increase when intruder pressure is moderate (few intruders) and decrease when intruder pressure is overwhelming.

questions.question: A researcher wants to test whether cooperation in vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus) is based on reciprocal altruism rather than kin selection. What experimental design would best distinguish these hypotheses?
options: Observe blood-sharing only in wild populations and assume all sharing is between relatives

In a controlled colony with known pedigrees (from genetic analysis), systematically remove food from specific individuals to create a need for blood-sharing, then record who shares with whom — compare sharing rates between related and unrelated pairs while controlling for association time, roosting proximity, and grooming relationships; critically, test whether individuals preferentially share with previous donors (reciprocity) independently of relatedness, and whether non-reciprocators are punished by reduced future sharing
Measure genetic relatedness of all bats and correlate it with proximity in the roost
Simply count the number of blood-sharing events per night
questions.explanation: Distinguishing reciprocal altruism from kin selection requires disentangling the effects of relatedness from reciprocity. Gerald Wilkinson's (1984) classic study, and subsequent work by Carter and Wilkinson (2013, 2015), employed this approach: (1) Known pedigrees: Genetic analysis (microsatellites or SNPs) determines relatedness (r) between all colony members, controlling for kinship effects. (2) Controlled need: Food deprivation of specific bats creates a predictable need for blood meals. Vampire bats can die within ~60 hours without feeding, so blood-sharing is literally life-saving. (3) Behavioral matrix: Record all blood-sharing events, identifying donor and recipient. (4) Statistical analysis: Use generalized linear mixed models with both relatedness and reciprocity (past sharing by recipient toward the current donor) as predictors, plus control variables (association duration, grooming frequency, roosting proximity). If reciprocity predicts sharing independently of relatedness, reciprocal altruism is supported. (5) Critical test — partner switching: When bats from different colonies (unrelated, no history) are housed together, does sharing develop preferentially with those who reciprocate? Carter and Wilkinson showed that food-sharing relationships develop between previously unfamiliar, unrelated bats and that sharing is predicted by grooming history (building trust through low-cost interactions before costly sharing). (6) Punishment test: Do bats reduce sharing with non-reciprocators? This is expected under reciprocal altruism but not kin selection. Results: Both kin selection and reciprocal altruism contribute, but reciprocity explains sharing between non-relatives.

questions.question: Agonistic behavior includes all forms of conflict, from threats to combat. What does the war of attrition model predict about contest duration?
options: The war of attrition model (Maynard Smith, 1974) predicts that in symmetric contests where opponents cannot assess each other's fighting ability, the ESS is to persist for a random duration drawn from a negative exponential distribution — this means contest duration is unpredictable, and no fixed persistence time is an ESS because any fixed strategy can be beaten by persisting slightly longer; the model explains why some contests last much longer than average while most are brief
All contests should last exactly the same amount of time
The stronger individual always wins immediately with no time spent in assessment
Contest duration is determined entirely by territory size, not by the contestants
questions.explanation: The war of attrition (WoA, Maynard Smith 1974, Bishop and Cannings 1978) models contests where: (1) Two opponents compete for a resource by investing time/energy into the contest. (2) The individual that persists longer wins the resource (value V). (3) Both opponents pay a cost proportional to contest duration (cost rate c per unit time). (4) Neither can assess the other's commitment or fighting ability (symmetric contest with no information). The key insight: no fixed persistence time is an ESS. If all individuals persisted for time T, a mutant persisting for T + ε would always win. But if all persisted for T + ε, a mutant could avoid costly contests by giving up at T - ε and winning elsewhere. The mathematical solution: the ESS is a mixed strategy where persistence times are drawn from a negative exponential distribution with mean = V/(2c). Properties: (a) Average contest duration is proportional to resource value and inversely proportional to cost rate. (b) Most contests are short (the mode of an exponential distribution is zero), but some are very long. (c) The probability of winning at any moment is always 50-50 (the memoryless property of exponential distributions). The model has been extended to asymmetric contests (where information about RHP — resource holding potential — is available). In the sequential assessment model (Enquist and Leimar 1983), opponents gain information about relative fighting ability during the contest, and the weaker individual retreats when sufficiently certain of inferiority — this predicts escalation through increasingly costly display/combat stages.

questions.question: Sociobiology proposes that social behaviors have a genetic basis shaped by natural selection. What is the selfish gene perspective, and how does it explain apparent altruism?
options: Dawkins' selfish gene perspective (1976) reframes evolution as the differential survival of replicators (genes) using organisms as vehicles — altruistic behavior is not truly selfless at the gene level; genes promoting aid to relatives (who carry copies of the same gene) increase in frequency through kin selection, and genes promoting cooperation with non-relatives can spread through reciprocal altruism or mutualism; the organism's reproductive success is important only insofar as it propagates the genes
The selfish gene theory states that all organisms are purely selfish and never help others
The selfish gene theory proposes that groups of organisms evolve traits for the good of the species
The selfish gene perspective applies only to microorganisms, not to animals
questions.explanation: Richard Dawkins' The Selfish Gene (1976) popularized the gene-centered view of evolution, building on Hamilton's inclusive fitness theory. Core concepts: (1) The replicator — the gene (or more precisely, any stretch of DNA that is inherited with sufficient fidelity to be a unit of selection) is the fundamental unit of selection. Genes that are good at producing copies of themselves increase in frequency. (2) The vehicle — the organism is the gene's 'survival machine,' an ephemeral entity constructed by genes to propagate themselves. (3) Gene-level selection explains apparent altruism: (a) Kin selection: a gene that causes its carrier to help relatives (who are likely to carry copies of the same gene) increases its frequency even if the carrier's own reproduction is reduced (Hamilton's rule: rB > C). (b) Reciprocal altruism: a gene for helping non-relatives that is reciprocated can increase in frequency in repeated interactions (Trivers' model, tit-for-tat). (c) Green beard effects: theoretically, a gene could produce three effects simultaneously — a recognizable phenotype (green beard), recognition of that phenotype in others, and altruism toward bearers. The fire ant gene Gp-9 may be an example. (4) Apparent group selection effects can usually be explained by individual/gene-level selection. Group selection (selection between groups for traits benefiting the group) is theoretically possible but usually overwhelmed by within-group selection favoring selfish individuals. Multi-level selection theory (Wilson and Sober) argues both levels operate simultaneously.
